newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary says Romania vote outcome should boost ties.
newsitem.headline: Hungary says Romania vote outcome should boost ties.

text.p: Hungary said on Monday that Emil Constantinescu's victory in the Romanian presidential election should greatly improve the often-troubled relations between the two neighbours.

"I am convinced that bilateral Hungarian-Romanian relations will expand during Constantinescu's presidency," Hungarian Foreign Minister Laszlo Kovacs told the Hungarian MTI news agency after Constantinescu won in Sunday's second round.

He said that under Constantinescu, "the rights of the Hungarian minority (in Romania) will be enforced and Romania's Euro-Atlantic integration, its membership aspirations in NATO and the European Union, will receive a new impetus".

Hungary and Romania signed a basic treaty of friendship in September aimed at ending old quarrels by settling the status of Romania's 1.6 million ethnic Hungarians and guaranteeing Romania's western borders.
Hungary made no secret during the two-round polls of its preference for Constantinescu and his Democratic Convention (CDR) party, over the incumbent President Ion Iliescu, a Moscow-trained communist.
Hungary saw the CDR as more supportive than Iliescu of the basic treaty while ethnic Hungarians in Romania thought Iliescu's party was pitting them against majority Romanians for political purposes.
Kovacs said Constantinescu's stated commitment to democracy and pro-Western policies augured well for relations.

"The Hungarian side is ready to establish the highest-level contacts after the president and his government are sworn in, and to review the tasks of implementing the terms of the basic treaty and lend support to Romania's Euro-Atlantic integration efforts," Kovacs said.
